claim: If you dream of doing something, making a wish when you dream does not guarantee success.

supporting.text: Dreams are a product of subconscious activity and do not have the power to influence real-world outcomes.

attacks.text: Dreams are a product of subconscious activity and do not have the power to influence real-world outcomes.
Some studies suggest that dreams can influence motivation and decision-making, indirectly affecting real-world outcomes.
The influence of dreams on motivation is speculative and lacks robust empirical support.
There are anecdotal reports of people achieving success after dreaming about it, suggesting a possible causal link.
Anecdotal evidence is unreliable due to confirmation bias and lack of controlled conditions.

supporting.text: Success requires deliberate action and effort, which cannot be substituted by wishes made during dreams.

attacks.text: Success requires deliberate action and effort, which cannot be substituted by wishes made during dreams.
Some successful people attribute their achievements to subconscious motivation or inspiration gained from dreams, suggesting dreams can indirectly contribute to success.
Even if dreams provide inspiration, tangible success still requires conscious planning and execution, aligning with the original argument.
Psychological studies show that visualizing success (including in dreams) can enhance motivation and performance, acting as a form of mental preparation.
Visualization alone is insufficient without corresponding action, as demonstrated by cases where dreamers fail to implement their visions in reality.

supporting.text: There is no scientific evidence to support the idea that wishing in dreams has any causal effect on achieving goals.

attacks.text: There is no scientific evidence to support the idea that wishing in dreams has any causal effect on achieving goals.
Anecdotal evidence and personal testimonies suggest that some people attribute their success to positive visualization, including dreaming.
Anecdotal evidence is subject to confirmation bias and cannot establish causal relationships.
Psychological studies show that visualization techniques, including dreaming, can enhance motivation and focus, indirectly contributing to success.
While visualization may enhance motivation, it does not guarantee success, as external factors and execution are critical.

supporting.text: Dreams are often disconnected from reality and lack the agency to bring about tangible results.

attacks.text: Dreams are often disconnected from reality and lack the agency to bring about tangible results.
Some dreams, like lucid dreams, allow individuals to consciously influence outcomes, which can translate to real-world motivation.
Lucid dreaming is rare and requires extensive training, making it an exception rather than a norm.
Psychological studies show that visualizing success in dreams can improve real-world performance by reinforcing neural pathways.
Visualization alone is insufficient without real-world action, and dreams do not substitute for effort.

supporting.text: Wishing in a dream is a passive act, whereas success typically demands active engagement and planning.

attacks.text: Wishing in a dream is a passive act, whereas success typically demands active engagement and planning.
Some individuals report achieving success through visualization and subconscious manifestation, which can include dream-based wishes.
Scientific studies on visualization and manifestation often lack rigorous empirical support, making such claims speculative.
Passive dreaming can still inspire or motivate active efforts in waking life, indirectly contributing to success.
Inspiration from dreams is highly subjective and not universally reliable as a predictor of success.
